data.title: Excellent Food!
data.text: This place has a great environment and excellent food!  The staff was friendly, everything we had was delicious.  We can't wait to go back!!

data.title: Casual, good food
data.text: Limited menu, but thought-out and well prepare quality ingredients.  Very good French onion soup.  I'll return for certain.

data.title: Quiet but Quaint
data.text:
This is a nice Irish pub, with a nice bar. It's all very quaint, but very quiet the night my wife and I were there. And that was a Saturday night.
The food was good and roots music (recorded, not live) was perfect for the space. A pleasant stop.

data.title: Special place
data.text: This is a hidden gem. The bar is wonderful, I believe it came from the Wurst Hause in Cambridge. The food is farm to table, fresh and delicious. Good selection of micro brews, the bartenders are knowledgeable. I really enjoy this place! Great place to go with your friends.

data.title: Nice Find - Pub Food
data.text:
They don't have an extensive menu, however, tried the burger and it was good.  They offer mushrooms, cheese, lettuce and tomatoes as add-ons.  It was ordered as medium-well and it came more medium, but was still very good.

Waiter was good.  Food came fairly quickly after ordered.

Definitely will be back to try some of the other menu items.

data.title: drinks maybe not food
data.text: We came for light meal.  Hamburger, ordered 'medium,' was bleeding; heat had barely reached the center of the meat.  Waitress declared this was in fact medium.  Of course restaurants have differing idea of what medium is, but no definition matches that raw chunk we got.  My chicken pot pie was also disappointing - some good spice but thin.  Obviously the 'home made crust' was tossed on the top as dish was on its way to the table.  Definitely overpriced for quality.  Maybe good place for drinks.  We were the only customers on a cold night but with a lively crowd place might be good.  Just don't eat there

data.title: New Year's Day Brunch
data.text:
I came here with a group of friends for brunch on New Year's Day and it was absolutely perfect. I wouldn't expect to find a place like this in Malden and was really surprised. The interior still had up really nice Christmas decorations and little touches on the tables to celebrate the new year, like 2016 cocktail napkins and "Happy New Year" signs. I don't know why, but little things like that just make me really happy. 

I enjoyed the food as well. I got cheddar and maple grits and our table shared the bread pudding, which was to die for. The waitress was super friendly and accommodating, and allowed our table to order a few biscuits, even though they were not being sold separately on the menu (they were part of the biscuits and gravy brunch selection). I thought that was really nice, since she didn't even bat an eyelash and instead just asked us how many we'd like to order. 

The mimosas were served in really pretty red flutes and hit the spot. We were able to have a leisurely chat and hang out over some really great food. The music they had on that morning was also incredibly relaxing. I will definitely be back here for brunch again!

data.title: Again....still no disappointment
data.text:
So we've come to Ferry Street 4 more times since my first review.  We've brought friends and gone alone.  ALWAYS so good.  The Brussels sprouts are fanTAStic!  Kind and attentive service, great tunes, and a few TBS at the bar if you, like 8, like to keep an eye on the sports scores.

Never have had to wait either, which is, of course, icing on the cake.

data.title: Has potential
data.text:
We ate there for Sunday brunch. The place is a bit dark and the parking is in a municpal lot down the street. The staff is friendly and accommodating. I found that the food menu at brunch was very limited, but there is an extensive beer and drink menu. 
I had the vegetarian sandwich on focaccia bread. It sounded good with carmelized onions and balsamic vinegar. It arrived with home-made potato chips and home-made pickles. The pickles were too sweet for me, but the chips were a nice touch. The sandwich was dry with too much bread and too little filling. My husband had the breakfast tacos. he said they were good, not great and hard to eat. Overall the flavors were good and with some minor refinements the food could be even better. We will probably try it again for dinner.

data.title: Fun and yummy local pub
data.text: The owners of Ferry Street Foodand Drink met in culinary school. The chef is from Texas and his pulled pork sandwich was authentic and, according to my husband, delicious. The spicy brussels sprouts, pickled vegetables, and pate  are all divine. Cocktails are delicious and the atmosphere easy and pleasant to be in. Service is very good and sports games are on the TV at the bar if you're so inclined. All in all a local favorite.

data.title: A local gem finally!
data.text: So happy that a good neighborhood joint has opened up in Malden.    Restaurant and bar have been lovingly restored and the vibe is mellow and easy.    Staff is friendly and chef is on point.    Menu is simple and stays centered on what he does well.  Highlights are the burger and pate-can we put that on the burger please?

data.title: Wednesdays are $1.00 oyster nights!
data.text: We've been here several times on Wednesdays, mainly because they serve $1.00 oysters on the half-shell!  But other reasons to love Ferry St. are 1) although they are proud of their craft beers, they also stock Miller Lite in cans, which two of us love, 2)their battered fried green beans are spectacular, and 3) when two of us wanted to split a giant cheeseburger, Jason had two separate plates made up for each of us with half a burger, plus fries and pickles!  When I expressed my surprise and appreciation, he replied, "We aim to please!"  And they sure do please!

data.title: Great food, great atmosphere
data.text: The food is great, the staff is friendly and the atmosphere is fun!  You most certainly enjoy yourself here!

data.title: Comfort Food + ++
data.text: We read a very complimentary review in the Globe and a Saturday night 6:30 PM visit (called for reservations) confirmed it! Firstly, the service is the friendliest - professional yet relaxed. The small plates - olives, tempura green beans, mushroom arancini, home made chips - were salty heaven and well -sized. The entrees - especially the home made linguini - were delightful. The beer drinkers enjoyed small tastes and big glasses of a varied menu. We missed the Bananas Foster dessert but the dark chocolate pots o'creme and the creme brule were perfection. $150 for 4, including a bunch of drinks, was a fair price. We lingered for three hours in complete comfort. On our way out we noticed the bar, which also looked like just what everyone would like in their own neighborhood. Ferry Street is like a tavern of old - dark wood but enlightened everything else!

data.title: Maybe A Drink at the Bar
data.text: Recommended by a co worker. Dining area not impressive, some locals at the bar. The martini was ok, but I would not reorder.  The meatball appetizer was server cold, the cheesey grits were mushy.  Steak Frites very small portion, arugala wilted.  Burger was good, the onions & mushrooms saved this visit.  The fries were reasonably hot, pre salted.  No salt & pepper on the tables.  We opted to to bother with dessert.  If I were even tempted to go, it would be for a drink at the bar only.

data.title: unexpected awesome restaurant!
data.text: Where this is located I didn't expect to find such a great restaurant! The food is delicious! It's definitely a place that I could see being in the city and doing really well. They have a large selection of craft beers and authentic food. I'm not sure why it wasn't full, more people should go there.

data.title: Hidden gem in Malden - great craft beer and food
data.text:
This restaurant was a great find in Malden.  We have been here numerous times now and never left disappointed.  The craft beer options are great, and allow me to try different beers every time.  The menu is well rounded and concise, because they make everything in house!

Even if you are full at dessert time, order a dessert!  We are always dazzled by the delicious desserts, from the cookie skillet, the cobbler, or the bread pudding.

data.title: Great find in Malden!
data.text: There were four of us who met for dinner here, and we all had great experiences. There was a good selection of beer and drinks, and the menu was also very well rounded. Half our party was vegetarian, and we both opted for the veggie sandwich. We both thought the sandwiches were divine, with a great balance of sweet and savory, and the homemade chips were also wonderful. The meat eaters in the group also thoroughly enjoyed their meals. We ordered three desserts, the cookie skillet, the croissant bread pudding, and the crème brulee, all of which were also absolutely perfect. The atmosphere (old world pub) and the service (prompt, friendly, efficient, and with a smile) was also great. The prices were also extremely reasonable. We shall be back next time we're in town!

data.title: Cozy place with good craft beer and food
data.text: I went to this place on a Saturday night and it was not too busy.  The restaurant was playing good rock music at a reasonable volume so you could still carry on a conversation.  They had a great beer selection and food was good and reasonably priced.  I was told that everything was made at the restaurant including the hamburger buns.  I will be back.

data.title: Local knowledge helps to find this little gem
data.text: We were looking for somewhere to eat supper and our son who has recently moved to Malden with his wife suggested this restaurant. It was perfect. The staff are very friendly, everything is very clean and comfortable. The menu wasn't too large and everything we chose was delicious. We will definitely be going again.
